awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GEM--Thermal Electron Anisotropy in the Earth's Magnetotail
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most important problems of space plasma physics is understanding how high-energy charged particles are generated. There are a huge variety of mechanisms suggested for accelerating electrons in the region of the geomagnetic field known as the current sheet. This project will help distinguish between these theories to help determine which are at work in the magnetosphere. This is directly relevant to the National Space Weather Plan, since the work can lead to better models and forecasts of space weather, which affects national commercial and defense satellites and space-based communications. Additionally, graduate and undergraduate students will participate in the research.

This project quantifies the impact of the electron thermal anisotropy on the magnetotail current sheet structure and investigates the variation of characteristics of electron thermal anisotropy with geomagnetic activity. The anisotropic electron population can be responsible for generation of strong currents (induced by particle curvature drifts) and can serve as an energy source for various electromagnetic wave emissions. The project uses observations from five spacecraft missions (Geotail, Cluster, THEMIS, ARTEMIS, and MMS) covering the entire magnetotail within the radial distances from 10 to 80 Earth radii downtail. Using several years of THEMIS/ARTEMIS observations in the near-Earth and middle magnetotail, the work studies both the radial distribution of the electron thermal anisotropy and the impact of electron anisotropic currents on current sheet structure for different magnetotail configurations. Moreover, using MMS observations with the high-resolution plasma measurements the work will for the first time statistically reveal the fine structure of the electron anisotropic population and its contribution to the current density.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The structure and stability of the magnetotail current sheet (see schematic #1) determine the temporal and spatial characteristics of geomagnetic perturbations (e.g., substorms). Thus, current sheet properties have been extensively studied since the beginning of the space era. The principal role in current sheet dynamics is played by ion and electron current distributions. In typical magnetotail conditions, the electron current can dominate and determine the current sheet configuration. Such strong current of electrons, that are much colder than ions, are associated with electron thermal anisotropy, i.e. difference of electron thermal pressure components along and across magnetic field lines. Indeed, spacecraft observations suggest that electrons in the near-Earth magnetotail are predominantly parallel anisotropic with parallel pressure larger than perpendicular pressure. Such thermal anisotropy is the property of plasma, gas of charged particles moving differently along and across magnetic field lines. This project was focused on statistical investigation of such electron thermal anisotropy in the Earth?s magnetotail and on estimate the amplitudes of electron anisotropy-induced currents. One of the project features corresponds to investigation of electron anisotropy properties using the most comprehensive dataset consisting of measurements of five spacecraft missions at different radial distances (see schematic figure #2).

The main project outcomes are statistical results of the electron anisotropy contribution to the magnetotail current sheet configuration and mechanisms of electron anisotropy self-regulation.  Within this project we have demonstrated that a significant fraction (>30%) of all current sheets have an anisotropic electron current density >10% of the total current, whereas for a significant number of near-Earth current sheets, the anisotropic electron current can be >25% of the total current density. The main mechanisms regulating electron anisotropy level are (1) anisotropy increase by cold ionospheric electron outflow and (2) electron scattering and isotropisation by electrostatic waves, mostly consisting of electron cyclotron harmonic waves and broadband electrostatic turbulence. The important project results that such waves are generated by the same anisotropic electron population, and this balance of wave generation and electron outflow may provide a stable level of electron thermal anisotropy in the magnetotail. These results address the fundamental question (with the broad impact to space plasma community) of sources of electric currents in current filaments (current sheets) in the Earth?s magnetosphere, planetary magnetospheres, and solar corona.
